choices.text: Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey
Light blue → Lavender → Red → Grey
Grey → Red → Light blue → Lavender
Red → Lavender → Grey → Light blue

questions.text: The phlebotomist needs to collect samples from a patient for various tests. Among the options provided, which sequence of blood collection for testing ensures that the sample remains uncontaminated, considering the additives present in the collection tubes? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey

 

The Clinical & Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) has provided a recommended color sequence for collecting multiple venous and/or arterial blood samples from a single patient: Yellow, Pink, Light Blue, Red, Green, Lavender, And Grey.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The accurate color sequence for the blood collection tubes is as follows:

 

Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey

questions.text: The clinical finding in the 10-year-old boy includes fever, joint pain, and a hand lesion as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis based on these findings? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gottron's papules - Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

  • Juvenile dermatomyositis is a rare inflammatory disease affecting the skin and muscles. It typically presents in children with a characteristic skin rash and muscle weakness.
  • Gottron's papules are distinctive red or violet, raised, scaly lesions seen over knuckles (dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal joints), elbows, knees, and other extensor surfaces, highly suggestive of dermatomyositis.
  • The combination of fever, joint pain, and Gottron's papules strongly indicates juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Other features associated with Dermatomyositis are:

 

  • The Gottron's sign is a distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.

 

 

Gottron's sign: seen in the above image

 

  • Shawl sign or V-sign: Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution) as seen in the image below

 

 

  • Periungual telangiectasias: enlarged capillaries in the nail folds.

 

 

  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer.

 

 

  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid nodules - Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis:

 

  • Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder causing chronic joint inflammation in children.
  • Rheumatoid nodules are firm, painless, subcutaneous nodules that usually occur in areas of pressure but are not typically seen in the hands in this form.
  • The lesion in the image doesn't match the typical appearance of rheumatoid nodules.

 

Option C Sclerodactyly - Systemic sclerosis:

 

  • Systemic sclerosis is a connective tissue disease characterized by skin thickening and hardening (scleroderma).
  • Sclerodactyly refers to thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers and hands, leading to a claw-like appearance.
  • The lesion shown doesn't indicate the skin thickening or tightness characteristic of sclerodactyly.

 

Option D Mechanic's hand - Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • SLE is an autoimmune disease affecting multiple organ systems.
  • Mechanic's hand is a sign associated more with dermatomyositis than SLE, characterized by rough, cracked skin on the sides of the fingers, mimicking the hands of a manual labourer.
  • The presentation of mechanic's hand in SLE is less common and the symptoms described do not align well with SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case involving fever, joint pain, and hand lesions in a child, the presence of Gottron's papules is indicative of Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 53 page no 53.1-53.12

Harrisonâ€™s principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page 2820-2821

choices.text: Wide excision of the lactiferous duct.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure that involves the removal of a small segment of the lactiferous duct, typically from the breast in which a probe is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging. A tennis racquet incision is made, and the flap is dissected to reach the duct. The duct is then excised. This procedure is known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Microdochectomy

 

  • Microdochectomy is a surgical procedure that involves removing a discharging lactiferous duct.
  • The procedure is typically performed on patients with duct papilloma or duct ectasia involving a single duct.
  • During the procedure, a probe or stiff nylon suture is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging.
  • An incision can be made in the shape of a tennis racquet to encompass the entire duct, or a periareolar incision may be used to access the duct by dissecting the nipple flap.
  • The affected duct is then excised or removed, and the tissue is sent for further evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Macrodochectomy: Macrodochectomy refers to the removal of a larger or major segment of the lactiferous duct. This procedure can be undertaken when there are multiple pathologies within the duct, making it necessary to excise a more substantial portion of the duct system.

 

Option C. Cone excision: In breast surgery, it might mean the removal of a cone-shaped segment of tissue which includes a problematic area, such as a localized tumor. The goal is often to ensure that the margins of the removed tissue are clear of any pathological changes.

 

Option D. Wide excision of the lactiferous duct: This procedure involves removing a more extensive portion of the lactiferous duct, typically more than in a microdochectomy. The objective here might be to ensure that the entirety of a problematic duct or surrounding tissue is removed, especially if there is a concern about a larger segment of the duct being involved with a disease process.

 

Educational Objective:


Microdochectomy is the surgical removal of a discharging lactiferous duct, commonly performed for cases of single-duct pathologies like duct papilloma or duct ectasia.

questions.text: Patient presents with urinary complaints with sterile pyuria on urine-analysis. A cystoscopy shows dilated ureteric orifice. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Golf hole ureteric orifice

 

The clinical scenario describes a patient with urinary complaints and sterile pyuria, a condition where white blood cells are present in the urine without bacterial infection. The cystoscopy reveals a dilated ureteric orifice, which is characteristic of a golf hole ureteric orifice. This condition can occur due to functional obstruction or vesicoureteral reflux, where the ureteric orifice becomes dilated and appears abnormal on cystoscopy.

 

The key diagnostic clue here is the sterile pyuria combined with the specific appearance of the ureteric orifice on cystoscopy, pointing directly to a golf hole ureteric orifice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bladder diverticuli: Bladder diverticuli are pouches that form on the bladder wall and would appear as sac-like outpouchings rather than a dilated ureteric orifice. They are not typically associated with sterile pyuria.

 

Option C. Bladder ulcer: Bladder ulcers are characterized by mucosal erosions within the bladder and do not present with a dilated ureteric orifice. They may cause hematuria and pain rather than sterile pyuria.

 

Option D. Cystitis: Cystitis refers to inflammation of the bladder, often due to infection. It typically presents with symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria. In cystitis, cystoscopy would show diffuse bladder wall inflammation rather than a dilated ureteric orifice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dilated ureteric orifice seen on cystoscopy in a patient with sterile pyuria is indicative of a golf hole ureteric orifice, a condition where the orifice is abnormally dilated, often due to reflux or functional obstruction.

questions.text: Match the following : (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D
 

Explanation:

 

  1. Facial nerve - B. Taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue: The facial nerve (CN VII) is responsible for carrying taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It also controls the muscles of facial expression.
  2. Spinal accessory nerve - A. Shrugging of the shoulder: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) innervates the trapezius muscle, which is responsible for actions such as shrugging the shoulder and scapula elevation. It also contributes to head rotation.
  3. Glossopharyngeal nerve - C. Taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) carries taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue. It also plays a role in swallowing and provides sensory information from the throat and tonsils.
  4. Mandibular nerve - D. Chewing: The mandibular nerve (V3) is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) and is responsible for innervating the muscles of mastication (chewing), as well as providing sensory input to the lower jaw, teeth, and gums.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Carbon monoxide poisoning

questions.text: Identify the left curve, given the fact that the right curve is of adult hemoglobin.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

 

Explanation

 

  • The left curve is for myoglobin as it is a rectangular hyperbola curve which is characteristic of Michaelis Menton kinetics.
  • Fetal hemoglobin, CO poisoning and acidosis will shift the sigmoidal shape of hemoglobin saturation curve as shown in the image below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal hemoglobin: Fetal hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin, which shifts the curve to the left. However, the curve still maintains a sigmoidal shape.

 

Option C. Carbon monoxide poisoning: Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin with a much higher affinity than oxygen, shifting the hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left and making it more difficult for oxygen to be released to tissues. This also retains the sigmoidal shape.

 

Option D. Acidosis: Acidosis generally causes a rightward shift of the hemoglobin oxygen dissociation curve, reducing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen. This is the opposite of what is observed with myoglobin.

The left shift observed in the myoglobin curve reflects its high affinity for oxygen, distinguishing it from the sigmoidal curves seen in hemoglobin variations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myoglobin has a hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve due to its single polypeptide chain and high oxygen affinity, contrasting with the sigmoidal curve of hemoglobin due to its cooperative binding.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with a genital lesion as shown below. What is the best treatment option for her? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cryotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a genital wart, which is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), specifically referred to as condyloma acuminata. In the context of pregnancy, the treatment options for genital warts must be chosen with caution to ensure the safety of both the mother and the fetus.

 

Treatment Considerations in Pregnancy:

 

  • Cryotherapy: This method involves freezing the wart with liquid nitrogen, which is a safe and effective treatment for genital warts during pregnancy. It is widely preferred due to its safety profile and effectiveness.
  • Trichloroacetic acid is another safe option during pregnancy for treating genital warts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgical excision: Though safe, it is not the first-line treatment in most cases unless the warts are extensive.

 

Option B. Podophyllin: Not recommended during pregnancy due to safety concerns.

 

Option C. 5% imiquimod: Also avoided during pregnancy due to safety concerns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best treatment option for genital warts in a pregnant woman is cryotherapy, as it is safe and effective during pregnancy.

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucor

 

Histopathological staining shows broad septate, hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching, which suggests that it is more likely Mucor.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus: Aspergillus shows aseptate narrow hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Talaromyces: Talaromyces is a genus of fungi that forms septate hyphae and conidiophores.

 

Option D. Blastomyces: Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus that appears as broad-based budding yeast in tissue sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is identified by broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching, and it typically lacks rhizoids, unlike Rhizopus which has nodal rhizoids.

questions.text: A patient recovered from hepatitis B infection. Which of the following curve represents antibodies seen 4 weeks post-recovery? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti HBs

 

After recovery from hepatitis B infection, the patient will have antibodies against the hepatitis B surface antigen (anti-HBS), indicating immunity. The key points related to hepatitis B infection and recovery include:

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Initially present during the acute phase of infection, indicating active infection. It will eventually drop and become negative upon recovery.

 

Anti-HBc (Hepatitis B core antibody): Initially, anti-HBc IgM is positive during the acute phase, which then transitions to anti-HBc IgG as the infection progresses. The total anti-HBc represents both IgM initially and IgG later on.

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen): Indicates active viral replication and high infectivity. It decreases as the virus is cleared.

 

Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): The protective antibody indicating recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection. This antibody appears after the disappearance of HBsAg and is a marker of immunity post-recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti HBc: Anti-HBc indicates past or current infection with hepatitis B. Initially, IgM anti-HBc is present during the acute infection, and later, IgG anti-HBc persists. However, it does not specifically indicate recovery and immunity.


Option C. HBeAg: HBeAg is a marker of active viral replication and high infectivity. It is present during the active infection phase and decreases as the infection resolves.


Option D. HBsAg: HBsAg indicates active hepatitis B infection. It is present during the acute phase of infection and disappears upon recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-HBs antibodies indicate recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection. This is the only protective antibody that signifies the patient has successfully recovered from the infection and has developed immunity.

questions.text: The type of pelvis commonly associated with occipitoposterior and face to pubis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 

 

 

The anthropoid pelvis is characterized by a larger anteroposterior diameter compared to its transverse diameter, giving it a vertical oval shape. This type of pelvis is commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions and the "face to pubis" delivery pattern, where the baby's face presents toward the pubic symphysis during delivery. The anthropoid shape often causes the baby's head to rotate into a posterior position, leading to a higher likelihood of occipitoposterior presentations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gynecoid pelvis: The gynecoid pelvis is the typical female pelvis with a round shape and balanced anteroposterior and transverse diameters. It is most favorable for vaginal deliveries and is not commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions.

 

Option B. Android pelvis: The android pelvis is heart-shaped, narrower, and typically has prominent ischial spines. It is more commonly associated with obstructed labor and deep transverse arrest rather than occipitoposterior or face to pubis presentations.

 

Option D. Platypelloid pelvis: The platypelloid pelvis is characterized by a very wide transverse diameter and a flat shape, which often leads to delayed engagement of the fetal head. It is not associated with occipitoposterior positions but can lead to asynclitism and face presentations.

 

Educational Objective:


The anthropoid pelvis is the pelvic type most commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions and the "face to pubis" delivery pattern.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a palpable lump in her breast. Which of the following investigations cannot be used to rule out malignancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PET scan

 

In the evaluation of a breast lump or any suspicious symptoms, the triple assessment method is used. It involves clinical assessment, radiological examination, and cytological or histological examination. The combination of these three modalities has a high positive predictive value of 99.99% to exclude breast cancer.

 

Positron emission tomography (PET) scans are not typically used as part of the triple assessment method for breast cancer. PET scans use a radioactive tracer to produce detailed images of the body and are more commonly used to evaluate cancers that have spread to other parts of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiological investigations: Radiological investigations such as mammography or ultrasound are commonly used as part of the triple assessment method to evaluate a breast lump. These tests help to identify any suspicious areas in the breast tissue that may require further evaluation with a biopsy.

 

Option C. Clinical examination: Clinical examination, including physical examination and assessment of medical history, is an important part of the triple assessment method for breast cancer. This can help to identify any specific risk factors for breast cancer and assess the characteristics of the lump, such as size, shape, and texture.

 

Option D. Histology and cytology: Histology and cytology are essential parts of the triple assessment method for breast cancer. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) or core biopsy of the lump helps to establish a definitive diagnosis and determine whether the lump is benign or malignant. The sample is then examined under a microscope to determine the characteristics of the cells and provide further information about the tumor, such as the stage and grade.

questions.text: According to World Health Organization (WHO), blindness is defined as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VA < 3/60

 

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), blindness is defined as visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction. This definition has been in place since 2017 and has also been adopted by Indiaâ€™s National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI). The definition includes three criteria, any of which can classify a person as blind:

 

  1. Visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with best correction possible
  2. Visual field less than 10 degrees
  3. Inability to count fingers at 3 meters

 

Note â€“ VA < 6/60 was the old Indian criteria for blindness before 2017, where visual acuity less than 6/60 and visual field less than 20 degrees were considered blind. However, this is no longer the current WHO or Indian standard.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO definition of blindness, adopted since 2017, is visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with best possible correction, or visual field less than 10 degrees, or inability to count fingers at 3 meters.

questions.text: FAD status in body is determined by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione reductase

 

This is the correct answer. Glutathione reductase is an enzyme that contains FAD as a prosthetic group and plays a significant role in the reduction of glutathione disulfide (GSSG) to glutathione (GSH). The activity of glutathione reductase, which depends on the availability of FAD, can be used to assess tissue riboflavin (FAD precursor) status. Therefore, measuring the activity of glutathione reductase with and without FAD is a method for assessing FAD status in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is not directly involved in determining FAD status. Thiamine plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism but doesn't directly influence the levels of FAD in the body.

 

Option C. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is an enzyme involved in the first step of glucose metabolism, but it is not responsible for determining FAD status.

 

Option D. Transketolase: Transketolase is marker enzyme for B1 deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FAD is the active form of Vitamin B2 and marker for the B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity as this enzyme require B2 as coenzyme. So, in case of FAD deficiency, glutathione reductase activity will be lowered without affecting the quantity of enzyme.

 

Reference: Harperâ€™s 31st ed/pg- 534

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having nocturnal cough for last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The presence of eosinophilia in an immunosuppressed patient with respiratory symptoms and BAL revealing rhabditiform larvae is suggestive of disseminated strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Strongyloidiasis:

 

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous. The transmission of infection occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine. The larvae moult twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

 

The life cycle of strongyloides is shown below.

 

 

It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms.

 

The term larva currens (meaning 'racing larvae') has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in immunodeficient individuals.

 

Larva currens is shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae of nonhuman species of nematodes that infect via the oral route.

 

Etiological agents causing visceral larva migrans:

 

  1. ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿Human nematode: Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis.
  2. ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿Zoophilic nematode: Toxocara canis, toxocara cati, Angiostrongylus cantoniensis, Angiostrongylus costaricensis, Anisakis.
  3. ï»¿ï»¿ï»¿Non human nematode: Filarial species, Brugia pahangi, Brugia pate

 

Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:

 

  • ï»¿ï»¿Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
  • ï»¿ï»¿Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
  • ï»¿ï»¿Stool culture and serological tests are also done

 

Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma canium presents with creeping eruption. Cutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

Option B. Capillaria phillipinesis can also cause auto-infection. It commonly presents with severe diarrhea.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection presents as itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus)

 

Educational Objective

 

In patients presenting with respiratory symptoms and eosinophilia, especially those who are immunocompromised, strongyloidiasis should be considered. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent the severe outcomes associated with hyperinfection. Treatment typically involves antiparasitic medications such as ivermectin.

 

Autoinfection: - CHEST (Mnemonic)

 

  1. Cryptosporidium parvum
  2. H. nana larva
  3. Enterobius vermicularis
  4. Strongyloides
  5. Taenia solium

questions.text: Alpha 1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elastase

 

Alpha 1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme neutrophil elastase.

 

On serum electrophoresis, alpha-1-antitrypsin (-1-AT), also known as alpha 1-protease inhibitor, is a glycoprotein that typically makes up the alpha1-globulin fraction of the plasma proteins.

 

It is typically produced in the liver and found in macrophages, circulating blood, and tissue fluids.

 

The name "Alpha1-protease inhibitor" comes from the fact that alpha1AT's primary role in the body is to inhibit proteases. The proteases, particularly the elastases, come from neutrophils.

 

The anti-elastase activity of alpha1-AT prevents neutrophil elastase from digesting lung parenchyma, despite its ability to do so.

 

In the proteinase inhibitor (Pi) locus on chromosome 14, co-dominantly expressed genes that code for 1-antitrypsin are located. The Pi locus has a wide variety of alleles and is highly polymorphic.

 

Those who have the alpha1-AT deficit develop panacinar pulmonary emphysema.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase: Not primarily inhibited by A1AT; it is an antioxidant enzyme.

 

Option B. Collagenase: Also not a primary target of A1AT; these enzymes break down collagen in connective tissue.

 

Option D. Phospholipase: Not inhibited by A1AT; involved in the hydrolysis of phospholipids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha 1-antitrypsin's critical role is to inhibit neutrophil elastase, thus protecting connective tissue from inflammatory damage, particularly in the lungs and liver.

choices.text: Total lack of natural killer cells
Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM
Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections

questions.text: Which of the subsequent statements accurately describes the immunological anomaly associated with the absence of CD40 in B cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM

 

The absence of CD40 and its deficiency in B cells results in Hyper IgM syndrome. This condition is characterized by a reduction in IgG levels and an elevation in IgM levels.

 

HYPER IGM SYNDROME

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total lack of natural killer cells: This is not associated with CD40 deficiency but rather with other immune disorders like severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

 

Option B. Lack of CD8 mediated cytotoxicity: CD40/CD40L interactions do not directly affect CD8 T cells. CD8 mediated cytotoxicity is more related to T cell receptor function and MHC class I interactions.

 

Option D. Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections: While CD40 deficiency can lead to an increased susceptibility to infections, neutrophil function is not directly impaired by the absence of CD40. This function is more related to chronic granulomatous disease or other neutrophil defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgM syndrome is characterized by an increased level of IgM and decreased levels of other immunoglobulins like IgG, due to a defect in the CD40/CD40L interaction necessary for immunoglobulin class switching.

questions.text: A patient, who consumed a large number of TCA pills during a depressive episode, presented with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG. What is the next best step in treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NAHCO3

 

A patient presenting with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG following an overdose of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) requires immediate treatment to address the cardiotoxic effects of the overdose. The best next step in this scenario is the administration of intravenous Sodium Bicarbonate (NAHCO3). Sodium Bicarbonate is used to treat the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs, which is responsible for the wide QRS complexes. It works by alkalinizing the blood, which helps to mitigate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DC Cardioversion: This is generally used for unstable patients with life-threatening arrhythmias. In the case of TCA overdose, the priority is to treat the underlying cause of the arrhythmia (the sodium channel blockade), which is more effectively addressed with sodium bicarbonate.

 

Option B. Start antiarrhythmic drug: The use of antiarrhythmic drugs may be risky in the setting of TCA overdose, as these medications can exacerbate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect because there is a clear and specific treatment indicated for this scenario, which is the administration of Sodium Bicarbonate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadockâ€™s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 644.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with complaints of confusion and ataxia. Upon examination, nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wernicke's Encephalopathy

 

The presentation of a 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use, who is experiencing confusion, ataxia, nystagmus, and sixth nerve palsy, is highly suggestive of Wernicke's Encephalopathy. This is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Wernicke's Encephalopathy is characterized by the classic triad of confusion, oculomotor dysfunction (such as nystagmus and cranial nerve palsies), and ataxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Korsakoff Syndrome: This is a chronic neuropsychiatric syndrome that often follows Wernicke's Encephalopathy. It is characterized by severe memory impairment, confabulation, and behavioral changes but lacks the acute neurological symptoms such as nystagmus and ataxia seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option C. Delirium Tremens: This is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal characterized by delirium, tremors, agitation, hallucinations, and autonomic instability. While confusion is common, the specific neurological findings of nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy are more indicative of Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option D. De Clerambault Syndrome: Also known as erotomania, this is a delusional disorder characterized by the belief that another person is in love with the individual. It is unrelated to the symptoms presented in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernickeâ€™s encephalopathy is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is common in individuals with chronic alcohol use due to poor nutritional intake and absorption. Treatment include high dose of parenteral thiamine. Ophthalmoplegia responds first to the treatment, ataxia doesnt improve completely in almost 50% of cases.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadockâ€™s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with dysphagia, weight loss, and halitosis. What is the most probable diagnosis based on the image provided? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia

 

Achalasia is a condition characterized by the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax properly, leading to difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia), weight loss, and regurgitation. The typical radiological finding in achalasia is a smooth narrowing and gradual tapering at the lower esophagus, often described as a "bird's beak" appearance. The presence of dysphagia, weight loss, and halitosis (bad breath) in a young patient, along with the image showing smooth narrowing, points strongly towards achalasia. The halitosis, though mentioned, is often not a significant feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ca esophagus: This condition would typically present with progressive dysphagia rather than the intermittent dysphagia seen in achalasia. Halitosis is not commonly associated with esophageal cancer, and the radiological appearance would differ, showing irregular narrowing rather than the smooth tapering seen in achalasia.

 

Option C. Corrosive stricture: This would likely present with a history of corrosive ingestion and would show irregular, scarred, and narrowed areas of the esophagus, not the smooth tapering characteristic of achalasia.

 

Option D. Zenker's diverticulum: This condition can present with dysphagia and halitosis due to the trapping of food in the diverticulum, but the radiological appearance is quite distinct, typically showing a pouch at the pharyngoesophageal junction. The image provided does not suggest this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of dysphagia, weight loss, and regurgitation in a young patient, along with imaging showing smooth narrowing and gradual tapering, is highly suggestive of achalasia.

questions.text: Identify the plant (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cerebra Thevetia

 

Explanation:

 

Cerebra Thevetia (Yellow Oleander): This plant is identified by its yellow, bell-shaped flowers. It is also known as a cardiotoxic plant. The yellow oleander typically has these distinct flowers and should be recognized for its toxic properties.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nerium Odorum (White Oleander): White in color and not bell-shaped flower. It is also cardiotoxic.

 

 

Option C. Aconite: Also known as monk's hood, Aconite has hood-like flowers. It is characterized by a hood-like upper part and two-lipped lower part.

 

 

Option D. Cerbera odollam: Also known as the "suicide tree", it produces white flowers, mango like fruit and this is also cardiotoxic.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebra Thevetia (yellow oleander) - Yellow, bell-shaped flowers, a cardiotoxic plant.

 

Nerium Odorum (White Oleander) - White and flowers are not bell-shaped, also cardiotoxic

 

Note â€“ Other Important flowers

 

Trumpet shape flower â€“ Datura

 

 

Digitalis Purpura flowers â€“ arranged in elongated clusters, flower is tubular & pendant. Inside of the flower is heavily spotted

questions.text: Identify the sign? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Babinski sign


The Babinski sign is a reflex response where the big toe extends upward and the other toes fan out upon stimulation of the sole. This indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Ankle jerk: Reflex action at the ankle joint.
 

Option C. Jendrassik: Maneuver to enhance reflexes.
 

Option D. Normal plantar response: Flexion of all toes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Babinski sign indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.

questions.text: A patient presents incidentally with the following findings as shown below. He does not report any discomfort. According to the CEAP classification, what will be the C stage in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C2A

 

  • Given the scenario showing asymptomatic varicose veins, it corresponds to C2a in the CEAP classification system.
  • C2A: Represents varicose veins (C2) that are asymptomatic (suffix A).
  • The CEAP classification system is used to categorize varicose veins based on their clinical characteristics.
  • The acronym stands for Clinical, Etiologic, Anatomic, and Pathophysiologic factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. C2S: Represents varicose veins (C2) that are symptomatic (suffix S), meaning the patient would experience symptoms like pain, aching, swelling, or other discomforts. Since the patient reports no discomfort, this is not the correct classification.

 

Option C. C4a: This stage represents more advanced skin changes, such as pigmentation or eczema, due to chronic venous disease. The patient only has varicose veins without skin changes, so this classification is incorrect.

 

Option D. C1: Represents telangiectasia or reticular veins, which are smaller than varicose veins. The image and clinical description indicate larger varicose veins, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The CEAP classification system is essential for categorizing the severity and characteristics of venous disease.
  •  For asymptomatic varicose veins, the appropriate classification is C2a, distinguishing them from symptomatic cases and those with more advanced skin changes.

questions.text: A 23-year-old hypertensive man comes to the hospital, on examination, BP was 150/90 mmHg, and was afebrile. On further evaluation, serum renin was found to be normal. He was diagnosed with Connâ€™s Syndrome. All are true about the Connâ€™s Syndrome except: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

Connâ€™s Syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by the excessive secretion of aldosterone. Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to water retention, hypervolemia, and subsequently, hypertension. Additionally, aldosterone promotes the secretion of potassium and hydrogen ions via the renal tubules.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Connâ€™s Syndrome is characterized by excessive aldosterone secretion leading to metabolic alkalosis, hypertension, and low renin levels.

questions.text: Injury of the lower brachial plexus leads to Klumpke's paralysis. What is the characteristic clinical finding seen in this lesion? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Claw hand

 

The characteristic clinical finding in Klumpke's paralysis is a complete claw hand.

 

 

In Klumpke's paralysis, there's an injury to the lower brachial plexus, particularly affecting the C8 and T1 roots. This leads to weakness or paralysis of the small hand muscles, specifically those innervated by the ulnar nerve. Patients have hyperextension at the MCP joints and flexion at the IP joints of the 4th and 5th fingers, giving the appearance of a "claw hand". The "clawing" is most evident when the patient tries to extend the fingers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Policeman tip hand (also known as "Bishop's hand") : This deformity is characterized by hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion of the interphalangeal (IP) joints of the 4th and 5th fingers. It's seen in situations where there's a combined injury to both the median and ulnar nerves. This term, however, is not as commonly used in modern medical literature.

 

Option B. Wrist drop : This is seen with injury to the radial nerve. A patient with wrist drop will have difficulty in extending the wrist and fingers. This can be due to injury or compression of the radial nerve anywhere along its course, but often it's associated with injury in the axillary or upper arm region.

 

Option D. Horner's syndrome: Injury to the lower brachial plexus, especially the T1 root, can also involve the sympathetic fibers leading to Horner's syndrome, which is characterized by miosis (constricted pupil), ptosis (drooping of the eyelid), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side. While Horner's syndrome can be associated with a Klumpke's injury, it is not the most characteristic clinical finding for Klumpke's paralysis. The claw hand is more directly related to the primary neural injury of Klumpke's paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klumpke's paralysis, also known as Dejerine-Klumpke palsy, is a type of brachial plexus injury that affects the lower brachial plexus nerves (C8 and T1) that control the muscles of the forearm and hand.

 

Causes:

 

  • Brachial plexus injury involving the C8 and T1 nerve roots.
  • This injury can occur during childbirth if excessive force is applied during delivery or if the infant's shoulder becomes impacted in the birth canal.
  • Trauma, such as a fall or car accident, can also cause a brachial plexus injury and lead to Klumpke's paralysis.
  • Other less common causes include tumors or inflammation in the area.

 

Symptoms

 

  • Weakness or paralysis of the muscles of the hand and forearm,
  • Numbness or tingling in the hand and fingers, and a weakened grip.
  • In severe cases, there may also be a loss of sensation in the affected arm.

 

Treatment may include physical therapy, occupational therapy, and in some cases, surgery.

questions.text: A young male presents with suspected poisoning and has pin-point pupils. Which of the following can be the poison.  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Opioid
 

 

Educational objective :

 

Pin-point pupils are a classic sign of opioid intoxication and are crucial for identifying opioid overdose in clinical settings. Opioids act by stimulating mu-receptors, leading to reduced sympathetic tone in the eye, which results in constricted pupils.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with nonaxial proptosis of the left eye. The patient gives a history of a road traffic accident 15 years back. The CT image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Frontal mucocele

 

The given clinical scenario and the image findings are suggestive of a frontal mucocele.

 

A frontal mucocele is a benign cystic lesion that develops in the frontal sinus, which is one of the air-filled spaces located in the forehead region of the skull. It typically occurs as a result of the blockage or obstruction of the frontal sinus drainage pathway, leading to the accumulation of mucus within the sinus cavity. Over time, the trapped mucus can cause the sinus walls to expand, forming a mucocele.

 

 

Patient presents with headache, diplopia, and proptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal meningiomas: originates from the meninges, benign brain tumors presenting with headaches, seizures, vomiting, personality changes, and cognitive impairment. Given below is a Coronal MRI section.

 

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: is the most common benign tumor of nasopharynx. Patients present with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Pseudotumor of the orbit: is an idiopathic inflammation of the orbit presenting with painful proptosis, diplopia, and orbital congestion. Imaging shows right medial rectus muscle which is diffusely enlarged with moderate homogeneous enhancement with relative involvement of its tendinous insertion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal mucoceles are a significant cause of proptosis and orbital symptoms, particularly following a history of facial trauma or sinus disease. Prompt diagnosis and surgical intervention to decompress the sinus and restore drainage can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman was involved in a car accident two months ago, and she now complains of screaming and waking up in the middle of the night after having nightmares about the same incident over and over. Which of the following conditions does she have? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post traumatic stress disorder

 

This woman's presentation of recurrent nightmares about a traumatic event (the car accident) that happened two months ago suggests Post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). PTSD can develop after a traumatic event and involves symptoms such as re-experiencing the trauma (e.g., flashbacks, nightmares), avoidance of reminders of the trauma, negative alterations in mood and cognition, and increased arousal (e.g., irritability, difficulty sleeping).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute stress reaction: Acute stress reaction typically occurs immediately after a traumatic event and lasts for a few days to a few weeks.

 

Option B. Adjustment disorder: Adjustment disorder develops in response to a stressor and is characterized by emotional and behavioral symptoms, rather than the nightmares. It arises within three months of the stressor.

 

Option C. Mania: Mania is characterized by elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep, among other symptoms, and isn't directly related to a traumatic event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PTSD manifests after experiencing or witnessing significant traumatic event, with symptoms like flashbacks, nightmares,hypervigilance, exaggerated startle response,  severe anxiety centered on the event and avoidance of the situations that remind of the trauma. The symptoms must be present for at least one month. It is more common in females and young adults. Hippocampus and amygdala are implicated in the etiology of PTSD. Treatment includes trauma-focussed CBT (treatment of choice), SSRIs (Drug of choice), and eye movements desensitization and reprocessing.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadockâ€™s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 439-441.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has experienced the loss of her newborn. She is currently producing breast milk, leading to discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which of the following drug can be used to prevent this complication? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cabergoline

 

In this scenario, the goal is to prevent lactation to avoid discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. The appropriate treatment involves using a drug that can suppress prolactin secretion, as prolactin is the hormone responsible for stimulating milk production.

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that inhibits prolactin secretion, effectively suppressing lactation. It is often used for this purpose and can be an effective choice in this situation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: Mifepristone is an antiprogestin used for medical termination of pregnancy. It does not have a direct role in suppressing lactation.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine: Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic medication that can increase prolactin levels, which would not be helpful in this context.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent and antiemetic that also increases prolactin levels, making it unsuitable for suppressing lactation.

 

Given these options, the correct choice for preventing lactation and thus avoiding the associated complications is: b. Cabergoline

questions.text: Before conducting an A-V fistula procedure, which of the following tests is typically conducted? The image of the test is given below: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allen's test

 

The given image represents Allenâ€™s test, which indicates the patency of the radial and ulna artery in supplying the hand. Both arteries are compressed alternatively, to check if limb will survive in absence of radial artery (which will be now used in creation of AV fistula).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adson's test: Adson's test is a provocative test for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome accompanied by compression of the subclavian artery by a cervical rib or tightened anterior and middle scalene muscles. Patient is asked to turn his head to affected side and take a deep breath. Ipsilateral radial pulse will become weak in thoracic outlet syndrome.

 

 

Option C. Elevated arm stress test: Elevated arm stress test is a diagnostic tool used in the identification of Thoracic Outlet Syndrome. The patient is asked to abduct his shoulder and flex his forearm and open and close his fists. In presence of thoracic outlet syndrome, the affected limb will get cramps (ischemic) or paresthesia (neurogenic).

 

 

Option D. Nicoladoni's test: Nicoladoni's test is to be elicited in cases of AV fistula. There is slowing of heart rate in response to manual compression of fistula.

questions.text: There were 4000 live births in a community in a year. Do MMR Calculation if you come to know that 6 women died during pregnancy, labor/delivery, or within 42 days of delivery - 2 due to Obstructed labor, 1 due to Sepsis, 1 due to PPH, 1 due to Snake bite and 1 due to electrocution. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 100

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated using the formula:

 

 

In this scenario, there were 4000 live births in the community.

 

Calculation of Maternal Deaths:

 

  • Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman during pregnancy, labor, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, provided the death is related to maternity or its complications.
  • Out of the 6 reported deaths:
    • 2 deaths due to Obstructed labor (included)
    • 1 death due to Sepsis (included)
    • 1 death due to PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage) (included)
    • 1 death due to Snake bite (not related to maternity, hence excluded)
    • 1 death due to Electrocution (not related to maternity, hence excluded)

 

Therefore, only 4 deaths are considered maternal deaths.

 

Substituting in the formula:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, considering only deaths directly related to pregnancy or its complications.

questions.text: Match the following (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4, E-5

 

The correct matching of the items is as follows:

 

  • Eonism (Transvestism): Wearing clothes of the opposite sex, often for sexual gratification or due to gender identity disorder.
  • Frotteurism: The act of rubbing one's genitals against another person, usually in a crowded place.
  • Necrophilia: Engaging in sexual activity with dead bodies.
  • Exhibitionism: The act of exposing one's genitalia to unsuspecting individuals.
  • Passive Algoglenia: Deriving sexual gratification from experiencing pain, also known as masochism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eonism (Transvestism) is wearing clothes of the opposite sex, Frotteurism is rubbing genitals against another person, Necrophilia is having sex with dead bodies, Exhibitionism is exposing genitalia to unsuspecting individuals, and Passive Algoglenia is gratification from experiencing pain.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD as he is always fatigued and has muscle cramps after exercise and the blood sample collected soon after exercise showed low glucose and lactate level. He became normal after resting for a while. Which of the following diseases is he most likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McArdle disease

 

McArdle disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type V): This condition is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme myophosphorylase, which is essential for breaking down glycogen into glucose for energy during exercise. In McArdle disease, individuals experience muscle cramps, fatigue, and myoglobinuria (the presence of myoglobin in the urine) after exercise due to the inability to access stored glycogen for energy. Low glucose levels and lactate buildup can occur during exercise in individuals with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hers disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI): Hers disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme liver glycogen phosphorylase. It primarily affects the liver and leads to difficulties in releasing glucose from glycogen stores in the liver. This condition typically does not manifest with muscle symptoms like cramps or exercise-induced symptoms.

 

Option C. Cori's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type III): Cori's disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme debranching enzyme. It primarily affects the liver and muscles and can lead to muscle weakness, liver enlargement, and hypoglycemia. However, it does not typically present with the specific exercise-induced symptoms described in the case.

 

Option D. Andersen disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV): Andersen disease is a rare condition caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glycogen branching enzyme. It primarily affects the liver and can result in liver fibrosis. It does not typically cause muscle cramps or exercise-induced symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for the varicose vein. He now complains of sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Saphenous nerve

 

The given clinical scenario in a patient with sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve. Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following varicose vein surgery.

 

Saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve.

 

Sensory Distribution: The saphenous nerve is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body and provides sensation to the anteromedial aspect of the leg down to the medial side of the foot.

 

Clinical Relevance: Injury to the saphenous nerve, particularly during varicose vein surgery given its proximity to the great saphenous vein, would result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sural nerve:  It is formed by the joining of branches from the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It supplies sensation to the lateral and posterior aspect of the lower leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the sural nerve would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option B. Superficial peroneal nerve:  Branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It provides sensation to the anterolateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum (top) of the foot, excluding the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Damage to this nerve would cause sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot and the anterolateral aspect of the leg but not the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option C. Deep peroneal nerve: Another branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Its sensory distribution is limited and includes the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the deep peroneal nerve would affect the sensation between the first and second toes and would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following Amino acid needs to be supplied in the diet of patients with Cystathionine beta synthase defect? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysteine

 

Cysteine is not typically restricted in the diet of patients with CBS deficiency. In fact, cysteine supplementation may be necessary in some cases because CBS deficiency can lead to a decreased ability to convert homocysteine into cysteine. However, this decision is made on an individual basis after assessing the patient's specific needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methionine: Methionine is usually restricted in the diet of patients with CBS deficiency. Since methionine is metabolized to homocysteine, limiting dietary methionine intake can help reduce homocysteine levels in these patients.

 

Option C. Serine: Serine is not typically restricted in the diet of CBS-deficient patients. It is not directly related to homocysteine metabolism, so it does not require special dietary adjustments.

 

Option D. Homocysteine: Homocysteine is not supplied in the diet but rather accumulates in the body as a result of CBS deficiency. Managing and reducing elevated homocysteine levels is the primary goal of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystathionine beta synthase (CBS) is involved in the synthesis of cysteine from dietary methionine. Cysteine synthesis require methionine, serine and vitamin B6. The reactions are summarized in the diagram:

 

 

So, in case of CBS deficiency there will be no formation of cystathionine and cysteine. so, cysteine becomes essential and needs to be taken in diet.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 291

choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

 

The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression located on the lateral aspect of the wrist and the base of the thumb. When the thumb is extended, this depression becomes more pronounced. The lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box is formed by extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus. When you extend and abduct the thumb, you can typically feel these tendons, especially the abductor pollicis longus, become taut along the lateral border of the wrist, outlining the snuffbox.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. It extends the thumb's distal phalanx. The abductor pollicis brevis is a muscle of the thenar eminence and doesn't directly contribute to the boundaries of the anatomical snuffbox. Its tendon is not found in this region; instead, it inserts into the base of the thumb's proximal phalanx.

 

Option C. Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis: As already mentioned, the extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. The extensor pollicis brevis, in conjunction with the abductor pollicis longus, forms the lateral boundary. However, they don't together form just one boundary of the snuffbox.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis longus contributes to the lateral boundary of the snuffbox, as mentioned above. The abductor pollicis brevis, on the other hand, doesn't form any part of the snuffbox boundaries.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which amino acid is not used for synthesis of hormones?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycine

 

Glycine is an amino acid that does not directly participate in the synthesis of hormones. While glycine is an important amino acid involved in many biological processes, including the synthesis of proteins, it is not a precursor for hormone synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: Tyrosine is a precursor for the synthesis of several important hormones, including thyroid hormones (thyroxine and triiodothyronine), catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine), and melanin.

 

Option B. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is converted into tyrosine in the body and, as a result, indirectly contributes to hormone synthesis. Tyrosine, derived from phenylalanine, is then used for the synthesis of various hormones.

 

Option C. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid that serves as a precursor for the synthesis of serotonin and melatonin, both of which are important hormones involved in regulating mood, sleep, and other physiological processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tyrosine, phenylalanine, and tryptophan are all aromatic amino acids that serve as building blocks for the synthesis of various hormones.

questions.text: Dose for a new drug is assessed in which phase of Clinical trial? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Phase 1

 

Phase 1: This phase involves testing the drug on a small number of healthy human volunteers. The primary objective is to evaluate the drug's safety profile, non-toxicity, and determine the appropriate dosage range. Maximum tolerated dose (MTD) is often calculated in this phase, which makes it crucial for dose assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phase 2: Phase 2 clinical trials are designed to assess the efficacy of a drug or treatment. These trials involve a larger group of participants (100) than Phase 1 and aim to provide preliminary data on whether the drug works in people who have a certain condition or disease. Phase 2 trials also continue to monitor the drug's safety and side effects.

 

Option C. Phase 3: Phase 3 trials are conducted on a larger scale to confirm the drug's efficacy, monitor side effects, compare it to commonly used treatments, and collect information that will allow the drug to be used safely. These trials involve a larger number of participants and provide the critical data needed for regulatory approval. Drugs launched post this phase.

 

Option D. Phase 4: Phase 4 trials occur after the drug has been approved for use by the FDA. These post-marketing studies monitor the long-term effectiveness and impact on the general population, including any rare or long-term side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: How muscle spindle able to detect the length while muscle is contracting? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nuclear bag fibers

 

Muscle spindles are sensory receptors within the muscle that detect changes in muscle length and the rate of change in length. They consist of intrafusal fibers, which include both nuclear bag fibers and nuclear chain fibers.

 

These fibers are dynamic and are sensitive to the rate of change in muscle length (velocity of stretch). They play a crucial role in detecting muscle length changes during muscle contraction by responding to the speed at which the muscle length is changing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nuclear chain fibers: These fibers are more static and respond to the absolute length of the muscle rather than the rate of change. They are not primarily responsible for detecting changes during contraction.

 

Option C. Golgi tendon organ: This sensory receptor is located at the junction of the muscle and tendon. It monitors tension rather than length changes in the muscle. It is more involved in preventing muscle damage due to excessive force.

 

Option D. Other muscle receptor: This option is too vague. The specific receptor responsible for detecting the rate of change in muscle length during contraction is the nuclear bag fiber.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nuclear bag fibers in the muscle spindle are responsible for detecting the rate of change in muscle length during muscle contraction, making them essential for proprioception and motor control.

questions.text: The spinal trigeminal nucleus forms the second-order neuron of which of the following sensations? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pain

 

The spinal trigeminal nucleus is located in the medulla and functions as a relay center, particularly for pain and temperature sensations from the face. It processes these sensations and transmits the information to higher brain centers for interpretation. The second-order neurons in the spinal trigeminal nucleus specifically relay pain and temperature information, making it a critical component in the sensory pathway for these modalities.

 

The spinal trigeminal nucleus does not act as a relay center for other sensations like touch, two-point discrimination, or conscious proprioception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Touch: The sensation of touch is primarily processed through other pathways, such as the dorsal columns and the main sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, rather than the spinal trigeminal nucleus.

 

Option C. Two-point discrimination: This sensation is typically processed by the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway, not the spinal trigeminal nucleus.

 

Option D. Conscious proprioception: Conscious proprioception is also processed via the dorsal columns, particularly through the cuneate and gracile nuclei, and not the spinal trigeminal nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal trigeminal nucleus in the medulla serves as the second-order neuron relay center specifically for pain and temperature sensations from the face.

questions.text: All of the following are true about neutrophil extracellular trap except:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phagocytosis is enhanced

 

Explanation:

 

Phagocytosis is enhanced: This statement is incorrect. NET formation does not directly enhance phagocytosis. Instead, it is a distinct mechanism where the neutrophil traps and kills pathogens extracellularly, without engulfing them through phagocytosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are a defense mechanism employed by neutrophils to trap and kill extracellular pathogens. During NET formation, neutrophils undergo a process called NETosis, which involves chromatin decondensation and the release of DNA along with antibacterial enzymes into the extracellular space. This forms a mesh-like structure that can trap and kill bacteria.

 

Option A: Induced by sepsis: True. NETs are induced by various stimuli, including sepsis. In septicemia-like conditions, the presence of pathogens triggers the formation of NETs as a response to the infection.

 

Option C: Higher risk of SLE: True. NET formation also has some negative consequences. The exposure of nuclear antigens during NETosis can lead to an increased risk of developing autoimmune disorders, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The nuclear antigens released during NET formation can be recognized as "self" by the immune system, leading to the production of autoantibodies and the development of SLE.

 

Option D: Affected cell does not survive: True. In NET formation, the neutrophil undergoes a form of cell death called NETotic cell death. The affected neutrophil does not survive the process of NETosis, as it involves the release of its cellular contents, including DNA and enzymes. This process is sometimes referred to as "beneficial suicide" because the neutrophil sacrifices itself to create the extracellular trap that can capture and kill pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps are induced by sepsis, increase the risk of developing SLE due to exposure of nuclear antigens, and result in the death of the affected neutrophil, but they do not enhance phagocytosis.
